results.adx_keywords: Theater;Pop and Rock Music;internal-sub-only;Buffett, Jimmy
results.title: Jimmy Buffett Does Not Live the Jimmy Buffett Lifestyle
results.abstract: Mr. Buffett, who has a new Broadway show, “Escape to Margaritaville,” built a half-billion-dollar empire on his laid-back beach brand. But he’s all business now.

media.caption: Jimmy Buffett at the Marquis Theater on Broadway, where his new musical, “Escape to Margaritaville,” is set to open in March. “I don’t know anyone who wouldn’t spend a week on the beach,” he said.
media.copyright: Aaron Richter for The New York Times

results.title: Portugal Has Succeeded Where We’ve Failed With Addiction
results.abstract: Claims that decriminalization is harmful are not backed by evidence.

results.title: Anxiety in the Age of Barbie
results.abstract: Young women in crisis are wondering, “What was I made for?”

media.caption: Billie Eilish’s song “What Was I Made For?” has become the anthem of anxious and depressed young women.

results.adx_keywords: Music;Buffett, Jimmy;Chesney, Kenny;Jackson, Alan (1958- )
results.title: Jimmy Buffett Was More Than Beaches and Booze
results.abstract: There was wistfulness behind party tunes like “Margaritaville.” Buffett helped listeners feel like they’d earned the good times just by holding on.

media.caption: Jimmy Buffett, who built a business empire around the song “Margaritaville,” performs in Key West, Fla., in 2011.
media.copyright: Rob O'Neal/Florida Keys News Bureau, via Associated Press

results.adx_keywords: Research;Radiation;Nuclear Tests;Nuclear Weapons;Cold War Era;Environmental Science & Technology (Journal);Bavaria (Germany);Central Europe
results.title: Europe’s Boars Still Hold Radioactivity. What Surprised Scientists Is Why.
results.abstract: Some wild boar hunted in German forests have radiation levels that exceed the limit deemed safe for human consumption. New research suggests that it’s not just because of Chernobyl.

media.caption: A wild boar in the Bavarian Forest National Park in southern Germany.
media.copyright: Martin Zwick/Reda&Co/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images

results.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Ronen Bergman
results.title: ‘Es una revelación’: miles de mensajes de texto dan nuevas pistas del caso Ayotzinapa
results.abstract: Policías, militares y otros funcionarios se coludieron con un cártel que secuestró a 43 estudiantes en un caso que lleva casi una década sin resolverse. Unas intercepciones telefónicas muestran la ayuda que brindaron las autoridades al cártel en la desaparición masiva, y las circunstancias que llevaron a ella.
des_facet: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods

media.caption: Carteles en Ciudad de México de algunos de los 43 estudiantes que fueron secuestrados por la policía y entregados a un cártel en 2014 .
media.copyright: Luis Antonio Rojas para The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Black People;Sailboats and Sailing;Records and Achievements;Deaths (Obituaries);Oceans and Seas;Pinkney, Bill;Knox-Johnston, Robin;Mystic Seaport Museum;Cape Horn
results.title: Bill Pinkney, Globe-Circling Sailor Who Set a Racial Mark, Dies at 87
results.abstract: He was the first Black person to sail alone by way of the arduous southern route, rounding the perilous Cape Horn and withstanding storms and loneliness.

media.caption: Bill Pinkney in Chicago aboard his 47-foot cutter, Commitment, in September 1989. He set sail on his epic voyage the following August out of Boston.
media.copyright: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times

results.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Ronen Bergman
results.title: Why Did a Drug Gang Kill 43 Students? Text Messages Hold Clues.
results.abstract: The Mexican police, military officers and others secretly colluded with a cartel that kidnapped 43 students, a case unsolved after nearly a decade. Wiretaps show just how much the authorities helped the cartel behind the mass abduction, and what led to it.
des_facet: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
org_facet: Escuela Normal Rural Raul Isidro Burgos (Guerrero, Mexico)

media.caption: Posters in Mexico City of some of the 43 students who were kidnapped in 2014 by the police and turned over to a cartel.
media.copyright: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times

results.byline: By Mira Rojanasakul, Christopher Flavelle, Blacki Migliozzi and Eli Murray
results.title: America Is Using Up Its Groundwater Like There’s No Tomorrow
results.abstract: Unchecked overuse is draining and damaging aquifers nationwide, a data investigation by the New York Times revealed, threatening millions of people and America’s status as a food superpower.

results.byline: By Alan Feuer and Zach Montague
results.title: Two Proud Boys Sentenced in Jan. 6 Sedition Case
results.abstract: Ethan Nordean, a ground commander of the far-right group, got 18 years, matching the longest Jan. 6 sentence so far. Dominic Pezzola, among the first rioters to enter the Capitol, received 10 years.

media.caption: Dominic Pezzola, center right, confronting Capitol Police officers after breaking into the building on Jan. 6, 2021.

results.title: A Brutal Path Forward, Village by Village
results.abstract: As Ukraine pushes slowly forward in its counteroffensive, it’s relying heavily on the effort of hundreds of small-scale assault groups, each tasked with attacking a single trench, tree line or house.

media.caption: Ukrainian Army soldiers fire a self-propelled howitzer at targets in the direction of Bahkmut city on the eastern frontline, on Monday.

results.abstract: The fight over congestion pricing gets at something so very much bigger.

results.byline: By Mujib Mashal and Atul Loke
results.title: Quietly Crushing a Democracy: Millions on Trial in Bangladesh
results.abstract: The most active rivals to the country’s ruling party face dozens, even hundreds, of court cases each, paralyzing the opposition as a crucial election approaches.

media.caption: A rare rally by the political opposition in Dhaka, Bangladesh, in July. A few weeks later, the police crushed another opposition rally.

results.title: Partisan Politics Put a Huge Win for Public Health at Risk

results.adx_keywords: Romani People;Holocaust and the Nazi Era;World War II (1939-45);Jews and Judaism;Auschwitz Concentration Camp;Czechoslovakia
results.title: An Effort to Focus on Long Overlooked Roma Suffering in the Holocaust
results.abstract: As many as a half million Romani people were killed by the Nazis, according to one estimate. A new database tells the story of that genocide and its impact on individual lives.

media.caption: Helena Malíková, right, with a friend in Ostrava, in what is now the Czech Republic, circa 1949. Her experience during the Holocaust is now featured in “Testimony of Roma and Sinti,” a new database devoted to an expanded understanding of the Romani genocide of World War II.

results.adx_keywords: United States Politics and Government;Concussions;Brain;Epilepsy;Seizures (Medical);your-feed-healthcare;McConnell, Mitch;Senate
results.title: Mitch McConnell May Be Experiencing Small Seizures, Doctors Suggest
results.abstract: Two episodes, where the Republican senator froze and did not respond to some questions, may be symptoms of a serious illness, according to neurologists not involved in his medical care.

media.caption: Senator Mitch McConnell appeared to freeze for 30 seconds while responding to a question after an event in Covington, Ky., on Wednesday.
